Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Atomic Force Microscopy In-Situ in the Transmission Electron Microscope
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will combine the two primary experimental methods for characterization in nanotechnology, atomic force microscopy (AFM) and in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM), into one tool. The AFM allows high-resolution images to be made of the surface topography of a wide variety of different materials. The TEM allows structural and chemical characterization of the internal structure of a material with atomic resolution. This project will allow the incorporation of a fully functional atomic force microscopy (AFM) system into a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) sample holder, thereby permitting the complete range of versatile AFM experimentation to be performed coincident with electron beam microcharacterization. The end result will be an AFM that produces images and data in the same manner as commercial AFMs at comparable levels of quality and accuracy, all combined with simultaneous dynamic imaging of the tip-sample interface as well as the internal structure of the sample via the TEM. This will lead to advances in nanotechnology research and development through improved tools that combine the acquisition of nanoscale images of material structure with site-specific characterization of materials properties for cutting-edge research in the physical, biological and chemical sciences.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is rooted in the fact that atomic force and electron microscopy (AFM and EM) are primary tools for characterizing the structure of materials at nanometer length scales. As such, they represent cornerstone techniques in the areas of nanotechnology, condensed matter physics and materials science. Additionally, they are important diagnostic tools for sample characterization and failure analysis in the semiconductor industry, and have wide applicability in biological and medical research. Primary research efforts in these fields revolve around the need to create better experimental methodologies that permit improved understanding of the interrelationship between materials processing and the resulting interplay between microstructure and properties. In-situ experiments enabled by the instrumentation to be developed in this project will find increased use as methods to explore these interrelationships. The current rapid expansion of the field of in-situ EM and the growing EM market (10-15% per year) are additional factors that increase the commercial potential of this product to roughly $1-2 million annually, with an estimated growth rate equal to the broader EM market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project resulted in the development of a prototype of a scientific tool that combines the two primary experimental methods for characterization in nanotechnology: atomic force microscopy (AFM) and in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The AFM allows high-resolution images to be made of the surface topography of a wide variety of different materials. The TEM allows atomic resolution structural and chemical characterization of the internal structure of a material. In the course of this project we incorporated a fully functional atomic force microscopy (AFM) system into a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) sample holder, thereby permitting the complete range of versatile AFM experimentation to be performed coincident with electron beam microcharacterization. We demonstrated that sample topography can be measured using AFM while TEM image of AFM probe in contact with the surface is acquired. Ultimately, the end result of our project will be a commercial AFM for inside the TEM that produces images and data in the same manner as desktop AFMs at comparable levels of quality and accuracy, all combined with simultaneous dynamic imaging of the tip-sample interface as well as the internal structure of the sample via the TEM. The commercialization of this product will lead to the advance of nanotechnology research and development through improved tools that combine the acquisition of nanoscale images of material structure with site-specific characterization of materials properties for forefront research in physical, biological and chemical sciences.

AFM is a powerful platform for studies of functional properties of materials (electrical, mechanical, thermal etc.) at the nanoscale, while electron microscopy is a primary tool for characterizing the surface and internal structure of materials at the nanometer to sub-Angstrom lengths scales. Simultaneous AFM and TEM measurements ultimately will provide information about relationship between materials structure their properties with atomic resolution. Understanding structure – properties interplay in the materials is crucial for progress of various fields, such as nanotechnology, condensed matter physics and materials science (fields which see large support from NSF). Additionally, AFM and electron microscopy are primary tools for sample characterization and failure analysis in the semiconductor industry, at the same time techniques mentioned above have wide applicability in biological and medical research. The outcome of this Phase I project  shows the feasibility of a new experimental platform for studies of materials properties via the combination of high resolution probing of the surface structure of a material (AFM), along with dynamic images of the internal atomistic and chemical structure of the sample (TEM).


Last Modified: 01/25/2011
Modified by: Daan Hein Alsem
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project resulted in the development of a prototype of a scientific tool that combines the two primary experimental methods for characterization in nanotechnology: atomic force microscopy (AFM) and in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The AFM allows high-resolution images to be made of the surface topography of a wide variety of different materials. The TEM allows atomic resolution structural and chemical characterization of the internal structure of a material. In the course of this project we incorporated a fully functional atomic force microscopy (AFM) system into a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) sample holder, thereby permitting the complete range of versatile AFM experimentation to be performed coincident with electron beam microcharacterization. We demonstrated that sample topography can be measured using AFM while TEM image of AFM probe in contact with the surface is acquired. Ultimately, the end result of our project will be a commercial AFM for inside the TEM that produces images and data in the same manner as desktop AFMs at comparable levels of quality and accuracy, all combined with simultaneous dynamic imaging of the tip-sample interface as well as the internal structure of the sample via the TEM. The commercialization of this product will lead to the advance of nanotechnology research and development through improved tools that combine the acquisition of nanoscale images of material structure with site-specific characterization of materials properties for forefront research in physical, biological and chemical sciences. AFM is a powerful platform for studies of functional properties of materials (electrical, mechanical, thermal etc.) at the nanoscale, while electron microscopy is a primary tool for characterizing the surface and internal structure of materials at the nanometer to sub-Angstrom lengths scales. Simultaneous AFM and TEM measurements ultimately will provide information about relationship between materials structure their properties with atomic resolution. Understanding structure – properties interplay in the materials is crucial for progress of various fields, such as nanotechnology, condensed matter physics and materials science (fields which see large support from NSF). Additionally, AFM and electron microscopy are primary tools for sample characterization and failure analysis in the semiconductor industry, at the same time techniques mentioned above have wide applicability in biological and medical research. The outcome of this Phase I project shows the feasibility of a new experimental platform for studies of materials properties via the combination of high resolution probing of the surface structure of a material (AFM), along with dynamic images of the internal atomistic and chemical structure of the sample (TEM).
